page.title: 02Elkstone's church.
page.content: The church of St. John the Evangelist is Elkstone's most significant architectural feature, as it incorporates many notable examples of Norman work. The church has a carved tympanum above the south door which is said to be one of the best in the country. There are several other examples of carved stone work on the building's exterior. The tower was built in the Perpendicular style and replaced the Norman original which collapsed. The tower walls are over 1 metre in thickness and consist of hugh freestone blocks of local limestone. Within the tower is a set of 6 bells, the oldest dating from 1657. Next to the church is the Old Rectory which has a Queen Anne front and a tythe barn in its grounds.
